The reason I bought this games was for the story. After buying the third Half-Life I wanted to know the full story. The game was made in the 90s so the graphic are from that era; so in short, a younger person might not enjoy the game. It is pretty challenging on hard setting. IF you want full Half-Life story I would say buy it. Also has PVP servers.

Don't buy this game for singleplayer story mode. Old nostalgic contents, animations and vanilla menu doesn't exist which makes the game lose it all flavor. I recommend vanilla day one version v1.0 published by Sierra in 1998. You can get it from archive org, add me if you have any troubles on installing.

Archive org isimli sitede 1998 yayƒ±nlƒ±, deƒüi≈ütirilmemi≈ü CD i√ßeriƒüine sahip dosyalarƒ± indirin. Y√ºklerken sorun ya≈üarsanƒ±z bana mesaj atabilirsiniz.

Half-Life is one of the best games of all time. Even though it came out before I was born and the graphics are dated, this is still my favorite singleplayer game. Half-Life treads the line between Quake-style boomer shooters and Halo-style modern shooters. It retains some things from the former, such as running fast and having many weapons, while requiring tactics like Halo to succeed (at least when played on hard mode). One thing important to remember about Half-Life is that it expects you to play smart and observe your surroundings. In an earlier part of the game, you find a flooded room with a broken ceiling light. There is a vent that you need to crawl through to continue, however, the wires from the ceiling light are touching the water, causing you to take damage when you touch it. If you're playing smart, you might ask, "how could I turn the light off?" instead of just tanking the damage. The one downfall of Half-Life (ignoring Xen) is its graphics, as they encourage the player to lobotomize themselves and just shoot, like other older shooters.
